modules.title: Phishing Basics & URL Analysis
modules.description: Learn to identify suspicious URLs and email headers.

questions.text: Which of the following URL characteristics is a common indicator of phishing?
options: The domain name contains a misspelling (e.g., paypa1.com)
questions.correct: The domain name contains a misspelling (e.g., paypa1.com)
questions.explanation: Typosquatting is a common tactic where attackers register domains that look similar to legitimate ones.

questions.text: You receive an email from 'IT Support' asking for your password. What should you do?
options: Click the link and reset your password
Report it to the actual IT department via official channels
questions.correct: Report it to the actual IT department via official channels
questions.explanation: Legitimate IT support will never ask for your password via email. Verify through official internal channels.

question_bank.text: Which URL is most likely a phishing attempt?
question_bank.explanation: Phishers use typosquatting and long misleading subdomains to impersonate trusted brands.
question_bank.example: Example: go0gle.com or paypa1.com are common look-alikes.

question_bank.text: A bank email asks you to 'verify your account' using a link. What is the safest first step?
options: Reply asking if it is real
Open your bank site by typing the official URL manually
question_bank.correct: Open your bank site by typing the official URL manually
question_bank.explanation: Do not trust embedded links. Navigate to the official site through a known safe method.

question_bank.text: Which statement about OTP codes is correct?
options: OTP can be shared with IT support if asked
OTP must never be shared with anyone
OTP is safe to post in email threads
OTP is only used for social media accounts
question_bank.correct: OTP must never be shared with anyone
question_bank.explanation: Any request for OTP is a strong indicator of fraud or account takeover attempt.

question_bank.text: Urgency like 'ACT NOW' is commonly used in phishing because it:
question_bank.explanation: Attackers use urgency to trigger impulsive actions and bypass security checks.

question_bank.text: If you suspect a phishing email, what should you do?
options: Report it through your bank's official security channel
Send your password to confirm identity
Click the link to test it
question_bank.correct: Report it through your bank's official security channel
question_bank.explanation: Reporting helps SOC teams block threats and warn other employees.

question_bank.text: Which is the strongest password?
question_bank.explanation: Strong passwords combine upper/lowercase, numbers, and symbols, and are not easily guessable.

question_bank.text: What is the 'From' address in an email?
question_bank.explanation: Attackers can easily manipulate the 'From' address to look like a trusted source.

question_bank.text: An attacker calls claiming to be from Microsoft Support to fix a virus. This is:
question_bank.explanation: Tech support scams via phone are a common form of Vishing.

question_bank.text: You find a USB drive in the parking lot. You should:
options: Plug it in to see who owns it
question_bank.explanation: USB drives can contain malware that auto-executes when plugged in.

question_bank.text: What does HTTP (without S) mean?
question_bank.explanation: HTTP transmits data in plain text, making it vulnerable to interception.

question_bank.text: A friend sends a strange link on Facebook with 'Is this you?'. You should:
options: Ask them via another channel if they sent it
Share it to see if others can open it
question_bank.correct: Ask them via another channel if they sent it
question_bank.explanation: compromised accounts are often used to spread phishing links via DM.

question_bank.text: Tailgating is when:
options: You follow a car too closely
An unauthorized person follows an employee through a secure door
You eat lunch at your desk
question_bank.correct: An unauthorized person follows an employee through a secure door
question_bank.explanation: Tailgating bypasses physical access controls.

question_bank.text: PII stands for:
question_bank.explanation: PII includes data like names, SSNs, and addresses that must be protected.

question_bank.text: Locking your computer when leaving your desk is:
options: Optional if you trust your team
question_bank.explanation: Unattended unlocked computers are a major security risk.

question_bank.text: What is 'Spam'?
question_bank.explanation: While often just annoying, spam is a primary delivery vehicle for phishing.

question_bank.text: In the URL https://login.bank.com.secure-verification.xyz, the real registered domain is:
question_bank.explanation: The registered domain is the last two labels for most TLDs. Everything before it is subdomain and can be misleading.
question_bank.example: bank.com.secure-verification.xyz is controlled by the attacker who owns secure-verification.xyz.

question_bank.text: Which header is most useful to verify if an email was spoofed?
question_bank.explanation: Authentication results and relay path can indicate spoofing and suspicious sending infrastructure.

question_bank.text: A vendor requests a last-minute bank account change for payment. Best practice is to:
options: Verify using a previously known phone number or channel
Ask them to resend from a different email
question_bank.correct: Verify using a previously known phone number or channel
question_bank.explanation: BEC attackers often manipulate invoice details. Out-of-band verification is required.

question_bank.text: MFA fatigue attacks succeed when users:
options: Approve repeated push notifications to stop them
question_bank.correct: Approve repeated push notifications to stop them
question_bank.explanation: Attackers spam MFA prompts until the victim accepts one.

question_bank.text: A padlock (HTTPS) confirms:
options: The connection is encrypted, not the site's intent
The site is owned by the bank
question_bank.correct: The connection is encrypted, not the site's intent
question_bank.explanation: Phishing sites can also use HTTPS certificates.

question_bank.text: Ransomware is malicious software that:
question_bank.explanation: Ransomware denies access to data until a ransom is paid.

question_bank.text: What is a 'Man-in-the-Middle' (MitM) attack?
options: An attacker intercepts communication between two parties
A physical intruder in the server room
A virus that sits in the middle of the screen
question_bank.correct: An attacker intercepts communication between two parties
question_bank.explanation: MitM attacks occur when an attacker secretly relays and possibly alters the communication between two parties.

question_bank.text: Pretexting involves:
options: Creating a fabricated scenario to steal info
question_bank.correct: Creating a fabricated scenario to steal info
question_bank.explanation: Attackers create a pretext (e.g., posing as HR) to trick victims into divulging sensitive info.

question_bank.text: Which of these is NOT a form of Multi-Factor Authentication?
question_bank.explanation: MFA requires two *different* types of evidence (something you know, have, or are). Two passwords are just 'something you know' twice.

question_bank.text: What does DMARC help prevent?
question_bank.explanation: DMARC uses SPF and DKIM to verify that the sender is authorized to send on behalf of the domain.

question_bank.text: Sideloading apps on Android/iOS poses a risk because:
options: Apps bypass official store security checks
question_bank.correct: Apps bypass official store security checks
question_bank.explanation: Official stores scan for malware; sideloaded apps may contain malicious code.

question_bank.text: Using Public Wi-Fi for banking is risky because:
question_bank.explanation: Public Wi-Fi is often unencrypted or poorly secured, allowing attackers to sniff traffic.

question_bank.text: What is the first phase of the Incident Response Lifecycle?
question_bank.explanation: Preparation involves setting up policies, tools, and teams before an incident occurs.

question_bank.text: What is the purpose of hashing passwords?
options: To encrypt them so they can be decrypted
question_bank.explanation: Hashing is one-way; you cannot reverse it to get the original password, which protects it if the DB is stolen.

question_bank.text: Quid Pro Quo attacks involve:
question_bank.explanation: Attackers offer a service or benefit (e.g., 'I can fix your slow PC') in exchange for information.

question_bank.text: Which control best reduces the impact of credential phishing in a bank environment?
question_bank.explanation: Phishing-resistant MFA significantly reduces account takeover even if passwords are captured.

question_bank.text: After a confirmed phishing click, the immediate priority is:
options: Post about it on social media
Containment and credential reset where applicable
Ignore it because it's too late
question_bank.correct: Containment and credential reset where applicable
question_bank.explanation: Containment prevents lateral movement; credential resets mitigate unauthorized access.

question_bank.text: Why is lexical URL analysis useful for real-time phishing detection?
options: It requires downloading full web page content every time
It can be computed quickly from the URL string alone
It only works for one domain
It requires administrator privileges in the browser
question_bank.correct: It can be computed quickly from the URL string alone
question_bank.explanation: Lexical features provide fast signals suitable for browser-triggered scanning.

question_bank.text: What is a 'Drive-by Download'?
options: Unintended download of malicious code by visiting a compromised site
Manually downloading software from a USB
question_bank.correct: Unintended download of malicious code by visiting a compromised site
question_bank.explanation: Drive-by downloads exploit browser vulnerabilities to install malware without user interaction.

question_bank.text: DNS Tunneling is used for:
options: Bypassing firewalls to exfiltrate data via DNS queries
question_bank.correct: Bypassing firewalls to exfiltrate data via DNS queries
question_bank.explanation: Attackers encode data in DNS queries to bypass network filters that allow DNS traffic.

question_bank.text: Cross-Site Scripting (XSS) allows attackers to:
options: Inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users
question_bank.correct: Inject malicious scripts into web pages viewed by other users
question_bank.explanation: XSS executes malicious scripts in the victim's browser, often stealing session cookies.

question_bank.text: What is the main advantage of OAuth 2.0?
options: It allows delegated access without sharing credentials
It is older and more stable
question_bank.correct: It allows delegated access without sharing credentials
question_bank.explanation: OAuth lets users grant apps access to their resources without giving the app their password.

question_bank.text: In Public Key Infrastructure (PKI), the private key is used for:
options: Decrypting data sent to the owner and signing digital signatures
question_bank.correct: Decrypting data sent to the owner and signing digital signatures
question_bank.explanation: The private key is kept secret and used to decrypt messages or sign documents.

question_bank.text: The 'Shared Responsibility Model' in cloud security means:
options: The cloud provider is responsible for everything
The customer is responsible for everything
Security responsibilities are divided between provider and customer
question_bank.correct: Security responsibilities are divided between provider and customer
question_bank.explanation: Typically, the provider secures the cloud infrastructure, while the customer secures data and access.

question_bank.text: Volatility is a tool used for:
question_bank.explanation: Volatility is a framework for extracting digital artifacts from volatile memory (RAM) samples.

question_bank.text: What is 'SQL Injection'?
options: Manipulating SQL queries via input data
question_bank.correct: Manipulating SQL queries via input data
question_bank.explanation: SQLi allows attackers to interfere with the queries an application makes to its database.

question_bank.text: The core principle of Zero Trust architecture is:
question_bank.explanation: Zero Trust assumes no user or device is trustworthy by default, regardless of location.

question_bank.text: GDPR primarily protects:
question_bank.explanation: GDPR is a regulation in EU law on data protection and privacy.

question_bank.text: IOC stands for:
question_bank.explanation: IOCs are artifacts observed on a network or in an OS that indicate a computer intrusion.

question_bank.text: What is 'Spear Phishing'?
options: Targeted phishing at a specific individual or organization
question_bank.correct: Targeted phishing at a specific individual or organization
question_bank.explanation: Spear phishing is personalized and highly targeted, making it more dangerous than generic phishing.

question_bank.text: Leaving an AWS S3 bucket 'Public' is a risk because:
options: Anyone on the internet can potentially read/write data
question_bank.correct: Anyone on the internet can potentially read/write data
question_bank.explanation: Misconfigured public buckets are a leading cause of data breaches in the cloud.

question_bank.text: A 'False Positive' in a security alert means:
options: The system alerted on benign activity
question_bank.correct: The system alerted on benign activity
question_bank.explanation: High false positives cause alert fatigue for SOC analysts.

question_bank.text: PCI DSS applies to organizations that:
question_bank.explanation: Payment Card Industry Data Security Standard secures credit card transactions.

question_bank.text: Which encryption method is faster for large data?
question_bank.explanation: Symmetric encryption uses the same key for encryption and decryption and is computationally faster.

question_bank.text: 'Chain of Custody' ensures:
options: Evidence is handled properly and admissible in court
question_bank.correct: Evidence is handled properly and admissible in court
question_bank.explanation: It tracks the handling of evidence to prevent tampering during an investigation.
